reasoning: The critique targets a specific illustrative sub-claim in §2.3.4 about early space-resource allocation being path-dependent and prone to lasting moral error. That point supports (but is not necessary for) the essay’s broader “eutopia is fragile / no easy eutopia” thesis, so centrality is low-moderate. If the critique were fully right, it mostly strengthens the paper’s pessimism about default trajectories rather than undermining it; it mainly attacks a strawier framing (“pretends we can cleanly choose an allocation scheme reflectively”) rather than the core argument that many non-obvious moral failure modes exist. Still, it offers some independent empirical support that one particular failure mode (conquest + legal rationalization) is a strong attractor, so it modestly bolsters the ‘default bad lock-in’ worry and slightly shifts probability mass away from ‘easy eutopia’. Correctness is fairly high: the historical analogy (colonialism, path dependence, post hoc legitimation) is broadly credible, but it overgeneralizes (“default”/near-inevitable) and imputes a stronger assumption to the paper than is clearly present. Clarity is good and focused, with minimal dead weight and essentially one issue throughout. Overall impact on the position is limited (low centrality, only moderate refutation of what it attacks).
title: Historical patterns suggest conquest rather than reflective allocation is the default
